findings.title: ST - Stops Transactions
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to stop transactions and sales for all users excluding themselves by setting specific variables, potentially operating as a honeypot.

findings.title: ELFM - Exceeds Fees Limit
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to increase over the allowed limit of 25%. The owner may take advantage of it by calling the `setFee` function with a high percentage value.

findings.title: FRV - Fee Restoration Vulnerability
findings.description: The contract demonstrates a potential vulnerability upon removing and restoring the fees. This can occur when both `_taxFee` and `_redisFee` have been set to zero.

findings.title: RVD - Redundant Variable Declaration
findings.description: The contract declares certain variables that are not used in a meaningful way by the contract.

findings.title: RED - Redundant Event Declaration
findings.description: The contract declares certain events that are not used by the contract. As a result, these events are redundant.

findings.title: PVC - Price Volatility Concern
findings.description: The contract accumulates tokens from taxes to swap them for ETH, but the variable `_swapTokensAtAmount` can be set to a big number, triggering a huge token swap, which may lead to significant price volatility due to the token's highly volatile price.

findings.title: RSW - Redundant Storage Writes
findings.description: The contract modifies the state of certain variables without checking if their current state is the same as the one passed as an argument, resulting in redundant storage writes.

findings.title: RSML - Redundant SafeMath Library
findings.description: The usage of the SafeMath library adds complexity, overhead and increases gas consumption unnecessarily since Solidity versions greater than or equal to 0.8.0 have native functionality for arithmetic operations that revert to underflow and overflow.

findings.title: L02 - State Variables could be Declared Constant
findings.description: State variables can be declared as constant using the constant keyword to ensure immutability and decrease gas consumption.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The code does not follow the Solidity naming convention guidelines, which can affect readability and maintainability.

findings.title: L05 - Unused State Variable
findings.description: An unused state variable is a state variable that is declared in the contract, but is never used in any of the contract's functions.

findings.title: L07 - Missing Events Arithmetic
findings.description: Events are a way to record and log information about changes or actions that occur within a contract.

findings.title: L13 - Divide before Multiply Operation
findings.description: Performing divisions before multiplications may cause loss of precision.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The `^` symbol indicates that any version of Solidity compatible with the specified version can be used to compile the contract, which may lead to unexpected versions and vulnerabilities.
